comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: At that time, cycling was the preserve of the gentry and well-off. Bicycles were very expensive before mass production and besides, it would have been consider socially pretentious for anyone lower than middle-class to be seen cycling.

comment.author: 61225546@N02
comment._content: And look how they were dressed for their bicycle tour. Especially the ladies in their long dresses.

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/61225546@N02] ....and that's why ladie's bicycles traditionally have no crossbar.
In those days, cycling was the preserve of the wealthy and so when out on a leisurely cycle one had to look one's best....not let the side down.

comment._content: Shot is taken on the steps of the courthouse in Catherine Street Waterford

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: I think this is an Ariel tricycle. 'Veteran Motorcycles' by Jeff Clew has the following information: "Ariel, one of Britain's oldest motorcycle manufacturers, were quick to take advantage of a basic flaw in the De Dion Bouton design. Although Ariel used De Dion engine in their own motor tricycle, they mounted it forward of the rear axle, where its weight was better balanced and the stability of the tricycle improved. Later, a water-cooled cylinder head was introduced, so that the rear-mounted engine was less likely to overheat."

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Thank you! Evolution of the motor cycle in action...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
